Introduction

Vitiligo is an acquired depigmentation disorder characterized by the progressive loss of melanocytes, leading to focal, well-demarcated patches of completely depigmented skin and/or hair.  The prevalence is similar in all racial and ethnic groups; it can occur in all ages but is most common at age <30.  The condition has significant psychosocial implications.

Pathophysiology



The exact pathogenesis of vitiligo likely involves a combination of genetic and environmental factors (eg, sunburn, trauma) that result in a loss of melanocytes.  An autoimmune mechanism leading to melanocyte destruction is likely, supported by the presence of melanocyte-specific autoantibodies and a greater prevalence of other autoimmune diseases (eg, autoimmune thyroid disease, alopecia areata) in patients with vitiligo.  Other possible contributing factors include neurohumoral toxicity specific for melanocytes and melanocytic self-destruction (eg, production of toxic intermediates during melanin synthesis).

Pathology



Histological examination of the affected epidermis demonstrates the absence of melanocytes and melanin pigment in the basal epidermis, often with scattered lymphocytes at the lesion border.  Epidermal architecture is otherwise preserved, and melanocytes are present in unaffected areas.

Clinical presentation



Vitiligo presents as well-defined, completely depigmented macules and patches of skin that can progressively expand and coalesce (

image 1
,
image 2
).  Overlying sunburn can cause the lesions to acquire an erythematous appearance.



Key distinguishing features include:



  • Presence of distinct borders.
  • Absence of clinical signs of inflammation, such as significant pruritus, pain, or scarring (unless overlying sunburn is present).
  • Overlying depigmented hair (
    image 3
    ), likely reflecting decreased repigmentation of follicular reserve.


Vitiligo occurs most often at age <30; it affects all racial groups equally, although it is often more apparent in patients with dark or suntanned skin.  Common locations include the face, hands, mucosa (eg, oral, genital), and areas of chronic pressure or friction (eg, elbows).  Skin involvement and disease progression can range from limited to widespread patches covering large areas of the body.  In some patients, the presentation may be more severe, with rapid onset of widespread depigmentation.



The subtypes of vitiligo include:



  • Nonsegmental vitiligo:  Most common; may be further classified as limited (eg, acral, mucosal, acrofacial), generalized (involving multiple areas of the body, often with symmetric and bilateral distribution), or universal (almost complete skin depigmentation).
  • Segmental vitiligo:  More common in children; characterized by localized depigmentation, a pseudodermatomal distribution, and limited disease progression.

Diagnosis and evaluation



The diagnosis of vitiligo is usually made on clinical grounds, particularly when findings are classic and readily apparent.  If the findings are subtle, examination with a Wood lamp (

image 4
) can increase the contrast between pigmented and depigmented skin (due to differences in light absorption in melanocyte-free vitiligo lesions).



Vitiligo can occur as an isolated disorder but is often associated with other autoimmune conditions, most notably autoimmune thyroid disease (eg, chronic lymphocytic [Hashimoto] thyroiditis, Graves disease).  Therefore, many experts advise screening patients with vitiligo for thyroid disorders (ie, serum TSH level).  In contrast, specific antibody testing for other rarer autoimmune disorders (eg, diabetes mellitus type 1) or nonspecific antibody tests (eg, antinuclear antibody) in the absence of disease-specific symptoms is not recommended.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for vitiligo includes conditions causing skin depigmentation or hypopigmentation, including:



  • Tinea versicolor and other dermatophyte infections:  Caused by superficial yeast infection (eg, Malassezia species).  Patches can be hypopigmented; however, macules often retain partial pigmentation and fluoresce yellow on Wood lamp examination.  Lesions also have a predilection for the chest and upper back rather than the face and distal extremities (
    image 5
    ).  Dermatophyte infection of the scalp (ie, tinea capitis) is common in children but presents with red, annular, scaly patches (
    image 6
    ) and focal hair loss rather than hair and skin depigmentation.
  • Pityriasis alba:  Commonly seen on sun-exposed skin and associated with fine scaling.  In contrast to vitiligo, borders are ill-defined (
    image 7
    ).
  • Discoid lupus:  May be associated with hypopigmentation; however, patients typically have erythematous plaques with overlying scale and surrounding inflammation and scarring (
    image 8
    )
  • Postinflammatory hypopigmentation:  Presents as irregular areas of hypopigmentation following episodes of preceding inflammatory skin disease (eg, discoid lupus, psoriasis).  It is caused by redistribution of existing melanin within the skin and/or reduced transfer of melanin to keratinocytes with intact melanocytes.  In contrast, vitiligo is characterized by the absence of melanocytes.
  • Lichen sclerosus:  Characterized by white, atrophic plaques with scarring, which is not typically seen in vitiligo.  Lichen sclerosus is commonly located in anogenital regions (
    image 9
    ) and can sometimes be difficult to distinguish from vitiligo affecting the genital area (in which case, biopsy may be required).
  • Lichen planus:  Characterized by red-purple plaques and papules associated with significant symptoms (eg, pruritus, pain) with an overlying white, lacy pattern (ie, Wickham striae (
    image 10
    )).  Hypopigmentation is not seen.
  • Albinism:  Characterized by intact melanocytes but without melanin production due to absent or defective tyrosinase; can result in depigmentation of the iris, hair, and skin (unlike the patchy depigmentation seen in vitiligo due to absent melanocytes).
  • Alopecia areata:  Characterized by immune-mediated disruption of the normal anagen phase (
    image 11
    ) of the hair growth cycle, inducing onset of catagen phase.  This disorder presents with well-defined patches of hair loss, but hair and scalp are not depigmented
    image 12
    ).

Management



The management of vitiligo aims to halt disease progression, achieve repigmentation, and address cosmetic concerns.  Options include:



  • Nonpharmacologic options include cosmetic camouflage, such as makeup or self-tanners.
  • Pharmacologic options include topical corticosteroids, which are first-line for limited disease.  For more extensive or rapidly progressive disease, calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus) and/or systemic corticosteroids can be used.
  • Phototherapy is used for extensive or severe disease.  Narrowband ultraviolet UVB is most common; PUVA (psoralen plus UVA) is less common due to greater risks of adverse effects.

Complications



Patients with vitiligo have an increased risk of sunburn and skin cancer in depigmented areas and should be counseled to regularly apply sunscreen.  In addition, measures should be taken to assess and address psychological distress resulting from cosmetic disfigurement.

Prognosis



The long-term course of vitiligo is highly variable and unpredictable; skin involvement may remain limited or progress.  Most patients experience periods of stability intermixed with periods of progression, with development of new lesions and enlargement of existing ones.  A minority of cases can undergo rapid expansion with depigmentation of broad regions.  Other cases may show partial or complete repigmentation over time.



Although no treatment is curative, early treatment of rapidly worsening or extensive vitiligo (eg, systemic corticosteroids, phototherapy) may be associated with improved outcomes.

Summary



Vitiligo (

) is a chronic depigmentation disorder resulting from melanocyte destruction, most likely mediated by autoimmune mechanisms in combination with environmental factors.  Classic features include well-demarcated, completely depigmented macules and patches located on the face, near or on mucosal surfaces, and/or the extremities.  In some cases, the disease may be more widespread.  Diagnosis is typically clinical, and management includes topical and systemic therapies (eg, oral or intravenous corticosteroids, phototherapy).  Sunscreen is essential to reduce the risk of skin cancer in depigmented areas.  The course of disease is unpredictable, and patients should receive ongoing treatment and support with attention to psychological ramifications.
